Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

Hersey, MI 49639-8776

Capacity: 10

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health Services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 4/7/25, a youth at the facility crushed up medication and
snorted it with another youth. It's unknown where the staff were
when this occurred.
Investigation Interviews:
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via telephone on
4/8/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker and reported
Youth A has a history of substance abuse.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/10/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A
reported he takes five or six medications including Vyvanse,
Lexapro, advance, Seroquel, and was unable to recall the names
of the others. Youth A reported staff that are trained to pass
medication by putting the medications in a cup and providing the
cup of medications to the youth. The staff reviews each of the
medications with the youth. The youth then put the medication in
their mouth and drinks a cup of water. Youth A reported after
youth drink the water, the staff check in the youth’s mouth to make
sure the youth took the medication and have the youth move their
tongue up, down, to the sides to make sure the medication is not
still in their mouth. Youth A reported he has “cheeked”
medications before when he is mad or not in the mood to take his
medications, however, it has been a while since he has “cheeked”
his medications. Youth A reported he is not aware of any youth in
his house recently cheeking medications. Youth A reported some
female youth at another house at the facility will sometimes cheek
their medication and mix their medications and crush the
medications up in a bag and snort them (this is being addressed in
SIR# 2025SIC0000550). Youth A reported last Thursday a female
2

youth brought a bag of crushed up Trazadone to school and gave
it to him. Youth A reported he is not prescribed Trazadone. Youth
A reported he snorted the crushed Trazadone at school
throughout the day in the bathroom approximately three different
times. Youth A reported he slept well that night. Youth A reported
the female youth has a history of cheeking her medications
however he did not know how she was able to cheek them. Youth
A reported when he has cheeked his medication, he puts the pill in
the back of his cheek, so staff do not see it and then dries it out
with a paper towel. Youth A reported some youth will act like they
put the medication in their mouth, however, they will hold the
medication in their hand or slide it down their shirt sleeve. Youth A
reported some staff will check youth’s hands and shirt sleeves.
Youth A reported he was the only youth in his house that received
any of the crushed medication and no other youth snorted it with
him. Youth A reported he did get another bag of crushed
medications from the female youth the same day that was
supposed to be given to Youth D, but Youth A reported he never
gave it to him. Youth A reported the bag was hanging out of his
pocket and Youth C grabbed it from his pocket. Youth A reported
Youth C threw the bag on the floor, however, Youth B told Youth A
the bag was dumped out. Youth A reported Staff 1 was doing
pocket checks that day and asked to see his pockets. Youth A
reported Staff 2 also approached him and asked him to see his
eyes which Youth A reported Staff 2 told him his eyes were
“bouncing”. Youth A reported he did not know how staff found out.
Youth A reported he eventually told Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 he
snorted the medication. Youth A reported he told Staff 3 he was
high from the Trazadone. Youth A reported this was the first time
he received medications from any youth at the facility.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/10/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B
reported last week he noticed Youth A was “drowsy” on the way to
the gym. Youth B reported Youth A told him he had “something”
he got from “someone” and took a bag out of his pocket that had
white powder in it. Youth B reported he took the bag from Youth A
and dumped it outside the van when they got to the gym. Youth B
reported he did not recall who the staff was that was working with
the group when this happened and described the staff as being a
female 5’6” or 5’7”. Youth B was unable to provide any further
details about the staff. Youth B reported he did not recall who else
was present. Youth B reported the staff wrote down and said they
would tell upper management. Youth B reported he does not take
medications at the facility. Youth B reported this was the first time
3

he had seen any youth with crushed up medications or
medications that did not belong to him.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/10/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth C
reported he takes medications at the facility that are prescribed to
him. Youth C reported at medication time, a staff will give him a
cup with his medication, the staff watch him take the medications,
have him drink water, and then check his mouth to make sure he
took the medication. Youth C reported he has never cheeked
medication at the facility. Youth C reported he thought Youth D
had cheeked medication before. Youth C reported some of the
girls at the facility previously cheek medications and saved the
medication to use during the day to get high. Youth C reported he
did not know which specific female youth did this. Youth C
reported he was informed by Youth A about the girls cheeking
their medications about two to three months ago as they were
acting “weird” and Youth A told Youth C the girls were high from
taking one another’s medications. Youth C reported Youth A was
“acting weird” and described acting weird as Youth A being a little
high. Youth C reported he believed this was last week on
Thursday. Youth C reported while the youth were in the van Youth
A pulled out a bag that he said was Trazadone and showed him.
Youth C reported Youth A told him he was getting high off it.
Youth C reported he took the bag from Youth C’s hand and
dumbed the bag out the van door when they got to the gym. Youth
C reported after he dumped the bag, he threw the bag back at
Youth A and told Youth A he was stupid. Youth C reported this
was the first time he was aware of any youth getting medications
they were not supposed to have. Youth C reported he did not
know if any staff were aware of what was going on. Youth C
reported Youth A kept asking him for the bag back and Youth C
told Youth A he poured it out on the ground. Youth C reported he
did not recall what staff were present during this time.
Youth D was interviewed via teams meeting on 4/17/2025 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth D reported he takes
medication at the facility. Youth D reported staff that are trained to
pass medications put the medication in a cup and provide the cup
of medications to the youth with a cup of water. Staff watch while
the youth take their medications and drink water. Staff then check
the youth’s mouth with a flashlight to make sure the youth took the
medication, and the medication is no longer in the youth’s mouth.
Youth D reported staff also have youth “blow” to ensure there is
nothing hidden in their mouth. Youth D reported he has only
cheeked his medication once and was caught. Youth D reported
4

he is not aware of any youth cheeking medications at the facility.
Youth D reported he has never been given any medications from
any other youth at the facility.
Youth E was interviewed via teams meeting on 4/17/2025 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth E reported he does
not take medications at the facility. Youth E reported he is
unaware of any youth “cheeking” or passing medications around
at the facility. Youth E reported Staff 2 asked him a weeks ago on
a Thursday if he had witnessed any drugs being passed around,
but he had not.
Staff 1 was interviewed via teams meeting on 4/17/2025 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported Staff 2
asked him to do a pocket check on Youth A after Youth A got to
the gym from the CTC building. Staff 1 reported he talked to
Youth A and completed the pocket check as Staff 2 informed him
Youth A was passed something during the day at school in the
hallway. Staff 1 reported Youth A did not have anything in his
pockets. Staff 1 reported he was in the van with Youth A and other
youth while the youth were being driven from the CTC building to
the gym during the school day. Staff 1 reported Staff 5 was
driving the van, and he was in the van but never saw anything
passed in the van. Staff 1 reported Youth A seemed down that
day, but no other physical or behavioral differences were noticed.
Staff 1 reported he is trained to pass medication to youth at the
facility. Staff 1 reported the process for passing medications
included checking the Medication Administration Record (MAR) to
ensure correct medications are passed to the correct youth,
medications are placed in a cup, the youth are given the cup of
medication and a cup of water, the youth take the medication and
drink the water. Staff have the youth open their mouths and look
around in the youth’s mouth to ensure the youth took the
medication and the medications are not still in the youth’s mouth
by having the youth move their tongue around and look under the
youth’s tongue. Staff 1 reported if a youth has a history of
cheeking medications, staff will also have the youth blow to
ensure there are no medications remaining in their mouth. Staff 1
reported no concerns with any staff not checking to ensure youth
are taking their medications.
Staff 2 was interviewed via teams meeting on 5/5/2025 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported she walked
into the gym and was approached by Youth F who informed her
Youth A was passed medications while in transit to the gym. Staff
2 reported it was unknown if Youth A had taken the medications or
5

if he was still in possession of the medications. Staff 2 reported
she requested Staff 1 complete a pocket check on Youth A. Staff
2 reported a bag was handed to Staff 1 by either Youth A or Youth
F. Staff 2 reported she did not know what was in the bag,
however, was told, unable to recall by whom, it was a red powder
that was believed to be a crushed medication. Staff 2 reported
Youth A approached her after the pocket check and asked her
why she requested he have a pocket check done. Staff 2 she told
Youth A his eyes appeared “watery and were moving back and
forth”. Staff 2 reported she asked Youth A if he was ok, and Youth
A stated he was. Staff 2 reported she did not recall Youth A ever
telling her that he took a Trazadone. Staff 2 reported she did not
know if Youth A told any staff that he had taken any medication.
Staff 2 reported Youth A acted normal, and she did not have any
concerns with his health. Staff 2 reported she later heard, unable
to recall from who, that an unknown female resident at the facility
had been cheeking medications and passed the medication to
Youth A while in school and Youth A had the medication in the
van while in transit to the gym. Staff 2 reported she is trained to
pass medications at the facility. Staff 2 reported medications are
given to youth by placing the medications in a cup and the youth is
given the cup of medications with a cup of water. The youth are
watched as they take the medications from the cup and drink the
cup of water. Staff 2 reported after the youth has taken the
medication and drank the water, staff then check the youth’s
mouth by having the youth move their tongue up, down, to the
right, and to the left, have the youth pull out each side of their
cheeks, and place their finger in front of their mouth and blow out
as hard as the youth can to ensure the medication is not in the
youths mouth. Staff 2 reported she has found youth on one or two
occasions to still have medications in their mouth. Staff 2 reported
she has had the youth retake the medications. Staff 2 reported if
a youth is intentionally cheeking medications at the facility an
incident report is written to document.
Staff 3 was interviewed via teams meeting on 4/17/2025 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3 reported Youth A
was in the gym and when she came into work, Staff 2 suggested
Youth A be drug tested due to concerns about something that
occurred in school, however Staff 3 reported Staff 2 did not
elaborate any specifics. Staff 3 reported Youth A was acting
sleepy however no other abnormal behavior. Staff 3 reported she
watched the other youth as well and no one appeared to be out of
their normal character. Staff 3 reported Youth A sometimes gets
down and she couldn’t tell if Youth A was just down that day as to
why he appeared sleepy or if something else was going on. Staff
6

2 reported Staff 5 was also working. Staff 3 reported she checked
all the youths’ pockets after school that day as she does every day
after school and nothing was found. Staff 3 reported Youth A
never told her anything and denied Youth A telling her he was
high or had taken medications that did not belong to him. Staff 3
reported she is medication trained and reported the process for
passing medication to youth is as follows: youth are given their
medication in a cup with a separate cup of water. Youth take their
medications and drink water. Staff check the youth’s mouth and
have the youth lift their tongue to the roof of their mouth and sides
to ensure the medication is no longer in their mouth and then have
the youth blow so that if the medication was to be hidden in their
mouth, the medication would come out. Staff 3 reported youth are
kept in staff’s line of sight until all this has been completed to
ensure no cheeking of medication.
Staff 4 was interviewed via teams meeting on 5/14/2025. Staff
4 reported she did not see anything related to the incident nor did
Youth A report anything to her about crushed medications. Staff 4
reported she recalled Youth A making a comment to her one day
about feeling “super high”. Staff 4 reported Youth A had been on
Vyvanse and had been taken off the medication and was recently
restarted. Staff 4 reported she asked Youth A if it was due to his
Vyvanse and Youth said no and started to laugh. Staff 4 reported
she has experienced youth under the influence and in her opinion
Youth A was not under the influence or “high”, Staff 4 reported she
felt Youth A was “playing a game and trying to act like he was
high”. Staff 4 reported she did not recall Youth A specifically
having a pocket check on that specific day however reported the
facility frequently completes pocket checks so she could not recall
as the days ran together. Staff 4 reported she is medication
trained at the facility and reported when it is time to pass
medications youth take their medications and drink water while
staff watch. Staff check the youth’s mouth and have the youth lift
their tongue to the roof of their mouth and sides to ensure the
medication is no longer in their mouth and then have the youth
blow through their mouth with their finger in front of their mouth.
Staff 4 reported she had heard about one youth, unsure who,
cheeking medication in the last month and a half and she has
made sure to watch that youth even more during medication pass
time.
Staff 5 was interviewed via teams meeting on 5/8/2025 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 5 reported he had no
knowledge of Youth A passing anything in the van during transit.
Staff 5 reported he normally provides the transportation for youth
7

from the CTC center and did not recall the specific day in
question. Staff 5 reported he is not trained to pass medications at
the facility and does not pass medications. Staff 5 reported he
has no knowledge of any youth cheeking medication or passing
medications to one another.
Documents Reviewed:
• Eagle Village Residential Services Standard Operating
Procedures-Standards for Drug Administration: All
medications dispensed orally need to be followed by youth
drinking an entire 4 ounce glass of water in front of staff as
the witness. Staff are to view the inside of the youth’s mouth
after they drink 4 ounces of water. This includes the youth
lifting their tongue to the roof of their mouth, moving their
tongue to the right side of their mouth and then moving their
tongue to the left side of their mouth. Youth are then to pull
out each side of their cheeks for staff to view the inside of
their cheeks to ensure there is no medication being stored or
“cheeked”. Whenever a youth has cheeked a medication,
please write a Medication Incident Report and notify the
Residential Treatment Supervisor and the Medical Staff.
• Eagle Village Case Note for Youth A dated 4/7/2025: Around
4:30pm Youth A stated to Staff 4 that he “got high today and
had a great day” because of it. Staff 4 asked Youth A if it
was due to him being back on his medication that he recently
took a break from. Youth A reported “no. Well I am back on
that but that’s not it. I got high with something else”. Staff 4
notified on-call who informed her to write a case note.
• Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, and Staff 5’s personnel file: Staff 1,
Staff 2, Staff 3, and Staff 5 had no discipline. Staff 1 received
Medication training on 8/28/2024, Staff 2 on 3/4/2025, and
Staff 3 on 1/16/2025, Staff 5 is not medication trained and
does not pass medications.
• Staff 4’s personnel file: Staff 4 had one discipline dated
8/21/2024 for sleeping on shift. Staff 4 received Medication
training on 11/13/2024.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance. Based on interviews with staff
and youth, the facility is following their internal administrating
medication policy and staff are checking youth’s mouths. Youth A
reported he received crushed medication from female residents at
the facility and took the medication and informed Staff 2 he had
taken the medication however Staff 2 denied Youth A disclosing to
her he had taken any medication that did not belong to him.
8

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
• The facility continues to educate and train staff regarding
ensuring thorough checks of youth’s mouths after a youth
has taken medication including checking with a flashlight as
youth have indicated staff check however it depends on
how well the youth can hide the medication in their mouth.
• The facility educate staff to ensure youth’s sleeves are
pulled up prior to administering medication to ensure youth
are not able to put medication in their sleeves.
• The facility complete thorough checks of youth returning
from home passes to ensure youth are not bringing
medications into the facility.
• The facility ensure staff are positioned in transit to be able
to view all youth in the vehicle.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
5/21/2025
Jennifer Pastorick Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
May 23, 2025
Shannon (Shay) Mavis Date
WOC Area Manager
9
